org.gannacademy.cdf.graphics.curriculum

Class VisualSort

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.gannacademy.cdf.graphics.curriculum.VisualSort
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Runnable

    public abstract class VisualSort
extends Object
implements Runnable

    A visual representation of an array being sorted.

    This class is meant to be extended with a specific sort algorithm. For the visualization to work, the extending subclass should make use of a number of inherited methods and data fields:

    • list is an array of int that contains the data being sorted.
    • finger is an int that represents the current position being examined in the array by the sorting algorithm.
    • swap(int, int) is a method that swaps two elements of the array.
    • sleep(long) allows the extending class to control the delay between steps (and thus the speed of the animation).

    For example, a simple extending class might be:

     public class BubbleSort extends VisualSort() {
     public BubbleSort(DrawingPanel drawingPanel) {
         super(drawingPanel);
     }

     public void sort() {
         for (int pass = 0; pass < list.length; pass++) {
             for (finger = 0; finger < list.length - 1; finger++) {
                 if (list[finger] > list[finger + 1]) {
                     swap(finger, finger + 1);
                 }
                 sleep(25);
             }
         }
     }
 }

    This subclass of VisualSort could be animated in a simple AppWindow:

     public class Visualization extends AppWindow() {
     private VisualSort bubbleSort;

     protected void setup() {
         bubbleSort = new BubbleSort(getDrawingPanel());
         bubbleSort.begin(); // begins the sort
     }

     @Override
     protected void loop() {
         bubbleSort.update();
         sleep(5);
     }

     public static void main(String[] args) {
         new Visualization();
     }
 }

    Note that the sort() method is iterating over the list array using finger as the array counter. The sleep(long) delay after each comparison slows the algorithm down so that the update() method can be invoked to periodically display the current state of the array in your animation loop in your AppWindow.

    Author:
    Seth Battis

      The color of the list element indexed by finger
      protected static int INVALID
      A list index value that will prevent that index from being highlighted
      protected int[] list
      The list of data to be sorted
      protected static Color swapColor
      The color of the list elements affected by the most recent call to swap(int, int)
      protected static int swapVisualLifetime
      The number of frames to leave the positions of a swap call highlighted
      protected Rectangle[] visuals
      The visuals representing the list elements
